questions.text: 10-year-old child, treated with antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis, presents with periorbital edema. Blood work reveals eosinophilia, and urine microscopy shows WBC casts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of eosinophilia along with WBC casts in the urine of a patient after consuming a course of antibiotics indicates a potential diagnosis of allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN).

 

Pyelonephritis (Option A), Glomerulonephritis (Option C), and IgA nephritis (Option D) do not exhibit eosinophilic casts in the urine.

 

Causes of Eosinophiluria:

  • Atheroembolic kidney disease
    • Acute kidney injury due to fragmentation of atherosclerotic plaque while performing coronary angiography causes fragments to get trapped in the renal artery.
    • Renal function tests are deranged, post coronary angiography, and there is the presence of purpura all over the body of the patient.
    • Development of gangrene of toes post angiography.
  • Allergic interstitial nephritis
    • Acute kidney injury secondary to antibiotic intake
  • Schistosomiasis

questions.text: What is the usual method of collecting a sample of urine to detect UTI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Midstream catch

Explanation:

In a toilet-trained child, the usual method of collecting urine for evaluation of urinary tract infection is midstream catch.

This is preferred since it poses the least risk of contamination and is easy and non-invasive.

Methods of Urine Sample Collection:

  • Midstream Sample (Toilet-Trained Children):
    • Suitable for most toilet-trained children.
    • Clean the introitus before collecting the sample.
  • Voided Sample (Uncircumcised Males):
    • Prepuce must be retracted to avoid contamination.
    • Non-retractable prepuce can lead to unreliable, contaminated samples.
  • Catheterized or Suprapubic Aspiration (Children Not Toilet-Trained):
    • Preferred methods for children under 2 years old.
  • Adhesive Collection Bag:
    • Can be used in children not toilet-trained if the skin is disinfected.
    • Useful for negative urinalysis or culture; has a 99% negative predictive value.
    • Not recommended if immediate treatment is planned due to high contamination risk.
  • Suprapubic Aspirate: (Option C)
    • Rarely needed; generally not recommended unless there are specific concerns.
       

Contamination Concerns:

  • Bagged Specimen: Positive cultures can result from contamination, especially in females and uncircumcised males.
  • Contamination Risk: A high rate of contamination may occur, especially with mixed organisms.

The early morning sample (Option A) is for evaluating proteinuria and not UTI.

Starting stream collection (Option D) is not preferred as this can contain commensals that might give incorrect results.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy who presents with repetitive episodes of urinary tract infection. The mother reports that he urinates frequently but has a weak urinary flow and dribbling of urine. Upon examination, a palpable bladder is detected. What is the most sensitive investigation that can be employed to determine the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Micturating Cystourethrography

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of frequent urination, weak stream, dribbling and palpable bladder with recurrent UTIs indicates urinary tract obstruction due to vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • Micturating cystourethrography (MCU) is the most sensitive investigation for diagnosing vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • MCU is a specialized radiological study that involves filling the bladder with contrast material and taking X-ray images during urination, allowing visualization of the bladder outline, urethra, and detection of any retrograde flow of urine into the ureters (vesicoureteral reflux). It is also used to diagnose posterior urethral valves and neurogenic bladder.

 

Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR)

Definition

Retrograde flow of urine from the bladder to ureters and pelvis at rest or during micturition

Epidemiology
  • Present in 30-35% of children with febrile UTI
  • Conventionally considered a major risk factor for acute pyelonephritis and reflux nephropathy
  • Can cause morbidity during pregnancy

Diagnostic Methods

Primary Methods:

  • Radionuclide MCU (more sensitive for detecting VUR)
  • Direct or indirect radionuclide cystography
  • Regular radiologic imaging every 24-36 months for grades III-IV VUR

Additional Techniques:

  • Contrast-enhanced ultrasound
  • MR urography
  • Urinalysis and urine cultures (if symptomatic)

Follow-up Monitoring:

  • Weight and blood pressure measurements
  • Periodic radiologic cystogram

Prophylactic Antibiotics

Medications and Dosages:

  • Amoxiciilin: 10-12.5 mg/kg/day
  • Nitrofurantoin: 1-2 mg/kg/day
  • Cephalexin: 10-12.5 mg/kg/day
  • Cefadroxil: 5 mg/kg/day

Special Considerations:

  • Avoid cotrimoxazole in infants <3 months, and those with G6PD deficiency
  • Avoid nitrofurantoin in <3 months, G6PD deficiency, renal insufficiency
  • Cephalexin is the drug of choice in the first 3-6 months of life
  • Cefadroxil is an alternative agent in early infancy

Management Approach

For Low Grade VUR (I-II):

  • With UTI: Consider antibiotic prophylaxis and Bladder-Bowel dysfunction management
  • Without UTI: No therapy needed

For High Grade VUR (III-IV):

  • With BBD: Antibiotic prophylaxis until BBD resolves, manage BBD
  • Without BBD: Antibiotic prophylaxis until age 2 and >1-yr UTI-free

Additional Considerations:

  • Medical therapy based on the principle that VUR resolves over time
  • Prophylactic antibiotics maintain sterile urine and prevent UTI while awaiting resolution
  • Surgical correction indicated for breakthrough infections or parenchymal injury

Treatment Guidelines
  • Consider dietary modification and medications
  • Some patients require bladder retraining, anticholinergic medications
  • Clean intermittent catheterization may be needed
  • Liberal fluid intake recommended
  • Regular and complete bladder emptying is important
  • Avoid constipation
  • Close follow-up for breakthrough UTI

Outcomes
  • Tends to resolve by 10 years of age
  • Resolution rate 70-90% for grades I-III
  • 10-35% resolution for higher grades
  • Better outcomes with: younger age, lower grades, unilateral VUR

 

Ultrasonogram (Option A) is useful as an initial screening tool to visualize kidney size, shape, and hydronephrosis. However, it is not the most sensitive as it cannot provide detailed information about urinary flow dynamics or definitively diagnose vesicoureteral reflux.

Urine routine examination (Option C) is essential for diagnosing active UTIs and monitoring response to treatment, but it is not the most sensitive investigation as it cannot identify the underlying anatomical or functional abnormalities causing recurrent infections. It provides no information about urinary tract anatomy or voiding dynamics.

DMSA scan (Option D) is primarily used to detect and evaluate renal scarring from previous UTIs but cannot evaluate bladder and urethral function during voiding. While valuable for assessing renal damage, it doesn't help identify the underlying cause.
